bibl.author: Cody, William Frederick, 1846-1917
bibl.title: Route Book Buffalo Bill's Wild West Season 1899

revisionDesc.change: Adams, Deb; Boyce, Gary; Clark, Linda Initial encoding

div1.p: To any officer U. S Army to knows W. F. Cody (Buffalo Bill) or myself. Langdon is a good boy a Rooseveltean and a thoroughbred with all the ambitions of the true soldier.

figure.p: The Matthews-Northrup Up-to-Date Map of the United States. Showing Chief Cities and Trunk Lines. Also Published Indexed in Vest-Pocket Style. Copyright 1895, by The Matthews-Northrup Co., Complete Engraving and Printing Works, Buffalo and New York.

titlePage.titlePart: Containing Also the Official Routes Seasons of 1895, 1896, 1897, 1898.

list.head: Secretaries.
list.item: For Cody & Salsbury, L. E. Decker,
For Bailey & Cole, Jos. F. Quaid.

list.head: Treasurers.
list.item: For Bailey & Cole, Fred B. Hutchison.

list.head: General Staff.
list.item: M. B. Bailey, Sup't of Electric Lights.
Chas. Evans, Sup't of Baggage Stock.
W. W. Reedy, Sup't of Bronco Stock.
C. W. Ramsey, Sup't of Confectionery Dep't.
Wm. McCune, Officer of the Day.

list.head: Department of Publicity.
list.item: Louis E. Cooke, General Advance Manager.
Major John M. Burke, General Press Agent.
Frank J. O'Donnell, Contracting Press Agent.
Miss Maymie Jester, Special Press Agent.
Dexter E. Fellows, Special Press Agent.
S. H. Semon, General Contracting Agent.
E. H. Woods, Assistant Contracting Agent.
M. Manton, Chas. Curtis, Bill Inspectors.

list.head: Advertising Car No. I.
list.item: W. H. Alberts, Boss Bill Poster.

list.head: Opposition Brigade.
list.item: Herman Leschinsky, Frank Raymond, Bill Posters.
Miss Annie Oakley, Lady Rifle Shot.
Frank Butler, Manager for Miss Oakley.

list.head: Piece No. 1.
list.item: J. R. Myerly, Thos. Gibney, Chas. Wolff, Drivers

list.head: Piece No. 2.

J. F. Meade, Hugh Harkins, Cowboy String.
Naber E. Smith, U. S. Cavalry.
Marshall Ochoa, W. Dyer, Dewitt Genung, Chas. Kelly, Indian.
J. R. Ziegler, Driver of "Buffalo" Wagon.
Harry Murphy. In Charge of Buffaloes.

list.head: Performers and Curios.
list.item: J. G. Sheidler, King of Cards.
Ben Casper, W. F. Greiner, Venetian Glass Blowers.
J. McClellan, Ben Powell, Electrograph and Mind-Readers.

list.head: Confectionery Dep't.
list.item: C. W. Spadi in Charge of Supplies.

list.head: Agents.
list.item: Geo. Manchester, Agent for "Buffalo Bill's" History.
Wm. Smithey, Dressing Room and Backing.

div2.head: Big Top Stake and Chain, Nos. 6 and 11.

list.item: Fred Bowman, Accountant for Wild West.
Sam. T. Bitmead, Accountant for Keen & Langan.

Wild West Band No. 1
in wagon.
German Garde-Kurassiers of His Majesty, Kaiser Wilhelm II.

Famous Cowboy Band,
Mounted,
Wm. Sweeney, Leader.

Col. Teddy B. Roosevelt's
Rough Riders.

Wild West Band, No. 3,
on Chariot Tableaux.

Detachment Fifth U. S.
Artillery, Battery D.

div1.head: Official Programme.
div1.p: 1—Overture, "Star Spangled Banner," Cowboy Band, Wm. Sweeney, Leader.

2—Grand Review, introducing the Rough Riders of the World—Indians, Cowboys, Mexicans, Cossacks, Gauchos, Arabs, Scouts, Guides and detachments of fully-equipped Regular Soldiers of the Armies of America, England, Germany and Russia, a Color Guard of Cuban Veterans, and a squad of Hawaiian, Porto Rican and Filipino Rough Riders.
3—Miss Annie Oakley, Celebrated Shot, who will illustrate her dexterity in the use of firearms.
4—Race of Races. Race between a Cowboy, a Cossack, a Mexican, an Arab, a Gaucho, and an Indian, on Spanish-Mexican, Bronco, Russian, Indian and Arabian Horses.
5—U. S. Artillery Drill, by veterans from Capt. Thorpe's Battery D, Fifth Regiment. U. S. Artillery.
6—Illustrating a Prairie Emigrant Train Crossing the Plains. It is attacked by marauding Indians, who are in turn repulsed by "Buffalo Bill" and a number of Scouts and Cowboys.
7—Pony Express. A former Pony Post Rider will show how letters and telegrams of the Republic were distributed across our Continent previous to the building of railways and telegraph.
8—A Group of Mexicans from Old Mexico will illustrate the use of the lasso and perform various feats of horsemanship.

9—The Battle of San Juan Hill. Introducing detachments from Roosevelt's Rough Riders, Twenty-fourth Infantry, Ninth and Tenth Cavalry, Grimes' Battery, Garcia's Cuban Scouts, Pack Train, etc., etc.
Scene 1—A halt on the Road to San Juan.
(Several hours are supposed to elapse before the opening of the second scene.)
Scene 2—Storming the Hill.
10—A Group of Riffian Arab Horsemen will illustrate their style of horsemanship, together with native sports and pastimes.
11—Johnny Baker, Celebrated Young American Marksman.
12—Cossacks, from the Caucasus of Russia, in feats of horsemanship, native dances, etc.
13—Gymkana Race. Riders gallop, dismount, turn coat inside out, remount, gallop, dismount, light cigar, put up umbrella, mount and come in with unbrella up and cigar lighted.
14—Cowboy Fun. Picking objects from the ground, lassoing wild horses, riding the buckers, etc.
15—Indians from the Sioux, Arapahoe, Brulé and Cheyenne tribes will illustrate the Indian mode of fighting, war dances and games.
16—Military Musical Drill, by a detachment from the 16th Lancers (Queen's Own), British Army, and a detachment from the Garde-Kürassiers of His Majesty Kaiser Wilhelm II.
17—Sixth United States Cavalry. Veterans from Col. Sumner's celebrated regiment at Ft. Meyer, Va., in military exercises, and an exhibition of athletic sports and horsemanship.
div1.note: Note.—The men will wear the uniforms adopted by the United States Army on the frontier. The horses are Western range horses, used in this manner for the first time in history. The Army and National Guard use the "American" horse.
div1.p: 18—Attack on the Deadwood Mail-Coach by Indians, repulse of the Indians, and rescue of the stage, passengers and mail, by "Buffalo Bill" and his attendant Cowboys.
19—Racing by Indian Boys on Bareback Horses.
20—Three Minutes With the Rough Riders of the World.
21—Col. W. F. Cody ("Buffalo Bill") in his unique feats of sharpshooting while riding at full speed.
22—Buffalo Hunt, as it was in the Far West of North America, by "Buffalo Bill" and Indians exhibiting the last of the only known native herd of buffalo.
23—Attack on Settlers' Cabin and rescue by "Buffalo Bill" and a band of Cowboys, Scouts and Frontiersmen.
24—Salute, by the entire company.

div1.head: The Annual Spring Opening.
div1.p: The show was moved from "Ambrose Park" to Madison Square Garden for the opening of the season on Sunday, March 26th. The parade which was to have taken place on Tuesday, 28th, had to be postponed until the following day on account of inclement weather.

The first performance was given on Wednesday night, March 29th, before a crowded house. Several entirely new features were introduced in the programme, the chief being "The Battle of San Juan," which proved an instantaneous success.

On Friday, April 7th, the afternoon performance was given for the benefit of the orphans and inmates of the different asylums and institutions around New York. Altogether, thirty-one performances were given during the stay in the Garden, at each of which the Garden was well filled, while on several occasions the doors had to be closed for the night performance. The season proved the most successful ever given in New York.

div2.head: Mon. 17 and Tues. 18
Baltimore, Md.
P. R. R. 186.
div2.p: The trains, with the canvas, seats, etc., reached here Saturday morning. The show opened under canvas, in fine, warm weather, giving four performances to crowded houses. Harry Skeen, for several seasons our car repairer, died suddenly in the hospital here. Cowboy Nelson goes to the hospital with a bad case of blood poisoning.

div2.head: Wed. 19 and Thurs. 20
Washington, D. C.—P. R. R. 43.
div2.p: Arrived 6.30 A. M., a slight accident to first section having delayed us two hours. Weather warm and clear. Four performances were given here, at each of which the tent was crowded.

div2.head: Fri. 21
Richmond, Va.
P. R. R. and R., F. & P. 116.
div2.p: Arrived 7.30 A. M. Half-mile haul to lot. Weather clear; big business at both performances.

div2.head: Sat. 22
Staunton, Va.
C. & O. 136.
div2.p: Arrived 8.00 A. M. One-mile haul to lot. Weather clear; attendance big in afternoon, light in evening.

div2.head: Mon. 24
Lynchburg, Va.
C. & O. 141.
div2.p: The show did not reach town till 11.00 A. M. Flat cars were transferred to siding near lot, to avoid the long haul. Franz gets a fall, and is bruised up a little. Weather clear; business big.

div2.head: Tues. 25
Roanoke, Va.
N. & W. 53.
div2.p: Arrived 7.30 A. M. Lot about one mile from crossing. In spite of a steady rain, tent was well filled at both performances.

div2.head: Wed. 26
Bluefield, W. Va.
N. & W. 107.
div2.p: Only one performance was given here, owing to long run to next stand. The road to the lot was in very bad condition, and gave us a lot of extra work. Weather cloudy; rain at night; business very big.

div2.head: Thur. 27
Bristol, Tenn.
N. & W. 169.
div2.p: Arrived in three sections; first section did not get in till 12.30. One performance only, to big business.

div2.head: Fri. 28
Knoxville, Tenn.
Southern. 135.
div2.p: Arrived early. Lot very dusty. Weather warn and clear; big business afternoon and night.

div2.head: Sat. 29
Chattanooga, Tenn.
Southern. 111.
div2.p: A broken axle on flat car delayed the second section five hours. Weather clear; business light. Frank Ackie, an eight-horse driver, died suddenly of heart failure.

div2.head: Mon. 1
Nashville, Tenn.
N. C. & St. L. 151.
div2.p: Arrived 10.30 A. M. Two-mile haul to lot, which was in good condition. Weather very warm; large attendance at both performances.

div2.head: Tues. 2
Bowling Green, Ky.
L. & N. 72.
div2.p: Half mile to lot. Weather clear and very warm; attendance big in the afternoon, light at night.

div2.head: Wed. 3
Louisville, Ky.
L. & N. 114.
div2.p: Arrived 8.00 A. M. Three-mile haul to lot; afternoon attendance very large, fair at night; weather warm and clear.

div2.head: Thurs. 4
Madison, Ind.
P., C., C. & St. L. 110.
div2.p: Arrived early. Flat cars were taken down a grade of 325 feet to the mile, in order to unload near the lot; attendance light; rain during afternoon.

div2.head: Fri. 5
Indianapolis, Ind.
P., C., C. & St. L. 86.
div2.p: Arrived early. One-mile haul to lot. Clear weather; very big attendance at both performances.

div2.head: Sat. 6
Richmond, Ind.
P., C., C. & St. L. 68.
div2.p: Weather cloudy with rain at night. Lot very rough. T. J. McManus, a canvasman, fell from a wagon while leaving the lot and was instantly killed.

div2.head: Mon. 8 and Tues. 9
Cincinnati, O.
P., C., C. & St. L. 74.
div2.p: The first day here the rain kept the lot in very bad condition, and had a noticeable effect on the attendance. Tuesday, the weather cleared and the tent was crowded twice. During the night performance, the roof of an old pavilion gave way under the weight of three or four hundred rubbers, and several were seriously hurt. F. J. Healy of U. S. Cavalry detachment closes.

div2.head: Wed. 10
Dayton, O.
C., H. & D. 59.
div2.p: Arrived in town early. Weather cloudy; business good. Cowboy Tom Hunter has a fall from a bucker and is badly shaken up. Wittman of U. S. Cavalry fell and received several cuts and bruises.

div2.head: Thurs. 11
Springfiled, O.
C., C., C. & St. L. 24.
div2.p: Arrived about 4.00 A. M. Weather clear and warm; two good houses. Mike Quinlan is sent to the hospital, with a bad cut in the leg.

div2.head: Fri. 12
Columbus, O.
C., C., C. & St. L. 43.
div2.p: Arrived early. Very long haul to lot. Weather cloudy with rain. Lot very muddy; good business in spite of weather. Jas. Anderson, our former superintendent, pays us a visit.

div2.head: Sat. 13
Newark, O.
P., C., C. & St. L. 33.
div2.p: Weather, rain during afternoon; business fair. While the artillery detachment was going into action No 2 turned completely over, Pony Moore got his shoulder broken, Hudson, Davis and Triangle were badly cut and bruised.

div2.head: Mon. 15 and Tues. 16
Pittsburg, Pa.
P., C., C. & St. L. 165.
div2.p: Arrived at noon Sunday. Weather clear; very large attendance the first day, the doors being closed at evening performance. Pony Moore leaves for New York to doctor broken shoulder. The show was packed during a heavy thunderstorm Tuesday evening.

div2.head: Wed. 17
Tyrone, Pa.
P. R. R. 132.
div2.p: Arrived 11 A. M., having been delayed by wrecks along the line. A heavy rain puts the lot in such bad condition that the night performance is abandoned; attendance very light.

div2.head: Thur. 18
Williamsport, Pa.
P. R. R. 79.
div2.p: Arrived early, one-mile haul to lot. The bad weather stays with us, but the tent was well filled at both performances.

div2.head: Fri. 19
Wilkes-Barre, Pa.
P. R. R. 103.
div2.p: Arrived about 7.00 A. M. Two-mile haul to lot. Weather cloudy and cold; attendance good at both performances.

div2.head: Sat. 20
Towanda, Pa.
L. V. 78.
div2.p: Arrived early. Lot situated on top of steep hill. Weather very cold; attendance light. Frank Eldredge, a four-horse driver, was severely hurt, by being thrown from seat of wagon.

div2.head: Mon. 22
Scranton, Pa.
L. V. and C. of N. J. 96.
div2.p: Weather cleared, and a bright, warm day brings out a large crowd, making it necessary to close the doors on the afternoon performance. Frank Eldredge, the driver who was hurt in Towanda, was taken to the hospital here.

div2.head: Tues. 23
Easton, Pa.
C. of N. J. 119.
div2.p: Weather clear, a light shower during afternoon; big business at both performances. Visits are exchanged with the "La Pearl" show, playing at South Bethlehem, twelve miles from here.

div2.head: Wed. 24
Allentown, Pa.
C. of N. J. 17.
div2.p: Arrived early, everything being ready by 9.00 A. M. Weather clear; attendance big at both performances.

div2.head: Thur. 25
Pottsville, Pa.
P. & R. 71.
div2.p: Arrived 6.30 A. M. Weather bright and clear; business very big. The large horse tent was set on fire by a spark from the engine and was almost entirely destroyed.

div2.head: Fri. 26
Reading, Pa.
P. & R. 35.
div2.p: Arrived early. Weather clear; very large attendance at both performances. Mike Quinlan returns from the hospital at Springfield, O.

div2.head: Sat. 27
Chester, Pa.
P. & R. 68.
div2.p: Arrived 6.00 A. M., half-mile haul to lot. Weather clear and very warm; business light. To-night finishes the 100th performance of the season. Johnnie Baker injures his hand and is compelled to omit his shooting act.

div2.head: Mon. 29
Philadelphia, Pa.
P. & R. 12.
div2.p: Arrived here about 5.00 A. M. Sunday was spent painting the poles, etc., thus giving the show a brighter appearance. The weather for the opening day proved clear and warm, and a large attendance was on hand. Managers Jas. A. Bailey, Nate Salsbury, and W. W. Cole paid a business visit.

div2.head: Tues. 30
div2.p: Tuesday, Decoration Day, brings out a large attendance twice; weather clear.

div2.head: Thur. 1
div2.p: Thursday evening, a wind and rain storm threatened to break up the performance, but soon cleared off.

div2.head: Fri. 2
div2.p: Friday extra reserved seats were put in, to accommodate the large crowd in the evening.

div2.head: Sat. 3
div2.p: Saturday, weather continues clear and two good houses mark the closing day here. Fred Randel, one of the cooks, fell from car platform, while we were pulling out for Long Branch, and had his right foot cut off; he was taken to the hospital in Philadelphia.

div2.head: Mon. 5
Long Branch, N. J.
P. R. R. 94.
div2.p: Arrived 6.30 A. M. Two-mile haul to the lot, which is very dusty. Weather clear and warm; very large attendance at evening performance. Jack Joyce has a fall in the "Race of Races," and is badly bruised up.

div2.head: Tues. 6
Elizabeth, N. J.
P. R. R. 35.
div2.p: Arrived 7.00 A. M. Two miles to lot. Weather very hot; night attendance very big. Tom Dennis, an English lancer, sent to the hospital with a broken collar bone.

div2.head: Wed. 7
Yonkers, N. Y.
P. R. R. and N. Y. C. 35.
div2.p: Second section did not get in till 10.00 A. M., having been delayed at the ferry. Lot very small. Cook-tent and horse-tent about one half mile from the rest of the show. Weather very hot.

div2.head: Thur. 8
Poughkeepsie, N. Y.
N. Y. C. 58.
div2.p: Arrrived 6.30 A. M. Two miles to lot. Weather clear; business light. Jack Reilly, a driver, fell from a wagon, breaking his leg; he was taken to the hospital here.

div2.head: Fri. 9
Winsted, Ct.
C. N. E. 80.
div2.p: Arrived 7.30 A. M. Lot close to crossing, and in very bad condition. Weather cloudy; business fair.

div2.head: Sat. 10
Hartford, Ct.
C. N. E. 35.
div2.p: Arrived 6.00 A. M. Unloaded close to lot. Weather clear; big business at both performances. The lot shows the tracks left by us last season, and is very rough.

div2.head: Mon. 12
Boston, Mass.
N. Y, N. H. & H. and B. & A. 131.
div2.p: Arrived in town at noon Sunday, after a very slow and tedious run. A special grandstand had been erected in place of our usual reserved seats.
Monday opened in fair weather, to two good houses.

div2.head: Tues. 13
Wed. 14
div2.p: Tuesday and Wednesday the weather was warm and clear, and the attendance large at each performance.

div2.head: Thurs. 15
div2.p: Thursday we had a wet day, and the attendance fell off a little on this account. Visits were exchanged with the Pawnee Wild West play at Waltham.

div2.head: Fri. 16
div2.p: Friday, clear weather brings out a large crowd, and extra seats had to be put up for the night performance.

div2.head: Sat. 17
div2.p: Saturday, the closing day here, the two performances were given to good houses. Weather clear. Pony Moore returns from New York and resumes his work in the artillery detachment.

div2.head: Mon. 19
Brocton, Mass.
N.Y., N. H. & H. 20.
div2.p: Arrived early. Lot three miles from crossing. Weather warm and clear; big business at both performances.

div2.head: Tues. 20
New Bedford, Mass.
N. Y., N. H. & H. 31.
div2.p: Arrived 6.30 A. M. Two miles to lot. Weather clear; good business at both performances.

div2.head: Wed. 21
Newport, R. I.
N. Y., N. H. & H. 41.
div2.p: Arrived 6.00 A. M. An axle on the first section stock car broke and the car had to be left behind. Weather clear; good house at night.

div2.head: Thur. 22
Fall River, Mass.
N. Y., N. H. & H. 18.
div2.p: Arrived 5.30. Half-mile haul to lot. Weather clear; business fair. Pete Wallace, porter of car 54, was badly hurt by a fall from a moving train.

div2.head: Fri. 23
New London, Ct.
N. Y., N. H. & H. 84.
div2.p: Arrived 9.00 A. M. The parade was given and the doors opened on time. Weather cool; good attendance at both performances.

div2.head: Sat. 24
Willimantic, Ct.
C. Vt. 30.
div2.p: Arrived 7.00 A. M. Half mile to lot, which proves to be very soft. Heavy rain during afternoon; business fair.

div2.head: Mon. 26
Bridgeport, Ct.
N. Y., N. H. & H. 72.
div2.p: Arrived 5.00 A. M. A heavy rain all Sunday puts the lot in pretty bad shape, but a clear, warm day on Monday brings an enormous attendance at both performances. Johnnie Baker resumes his shooting act.

div2.head: Tues. 27
Waterbury, Ct.
N. Y., N. H. & H. 32.
div2.p: Arrived 5.00 A. M. One-mile haul to lot. Weather clear. The lot is situated quarter of a mile from the street; business very big.

div2.head: Wed. 28
New Haven, Ct.
N. Y., N. H. & H. 30.
div2.p: Arrived early. Three-mile haul to lot. Rain during afternoon, clear at night; very large attendance at evening performance.

div2.head: Thur. 29
Holyoke, Mass.
N. Y., N. H. & H. 62.
div2.p: Arrived 6.30, and unloaded close to lot. Weather clear; good attendance at both performances.

div2.head: Fri. 30
Springfield, Mass.
B. & M. 8.
div2.p: Arrived early and unloaded close to park. Weather clear; business big. Rough Rider McGinty has a fall and is badly shaken up.

div2.head: Sat. 1
Worcester, Mass.
B. & A. 55.
div2.p: Arrived 6.00 A. M. One-mile haul to lot. Weather clear; large attendance at both performances.

div2.head: Mon. 3
Salem, Mass.
B. & A. and B. & M. 60.
div2.p: Arrived early. One-mile haul to lot. Weather clear and very warm; business big at both performances.

div2.head: Tues. 4
Lawrence, Mass.
B. & M. 24.
div2.p: Arrived 4.30 A. M. Lot three-fourths mile from crossing. Weather clear and warm; big business. The cook tent was tastefully decorated, and our caterers, Messrs. Keen & Langan, prepared a special supper in honor of the Fourth, which was greatly appreciated by all.

div2.head: Wed. 5
Haverhill, Mass.
B. & M. 7.
div2.p: Arrived 5.00 A. M. One-mile haul to lot. Weather clear; business big.

div2.head: Thur. 6
Dover, N. H.
B. & M. 35.
div2.p: Arrived 4.30 A. M. Lot a mile and a half from crossing. Weather clear; business big at both performances.

div2.head: Fri. 7
Concord, N. H.
B. & M. 61.
div2.p: Arrived 6.30 A. M. Half mile to lot. Weather clear; attendance big at both performances.

div2.head: Sat. 8
Manchester, N. H.
B. & M. 18.
div2.p: Arrived 4.30 A. M. One-mile haul to lot. Heavy rain all day; business fair.

div2.head: Mon. 10
Lowell, Mass.
B. & M. 31.
div2.p: Arrived early. Lot one mile from crossing. Rain on Sunday followed by a clear day Monday: business good.

div2.head: Tues. 11
Fitchburg, Mass.
N. Y., N. H. & H. 66.
div2.p: Arrived 6.00 A. M. Weather clear; business big at both performances. Frank Read, assistant boss hostler, closes and his place is given to Frank McNall.

div2.head: Wed. 12
Greenfield, Mass.
Fitchburg. 55.
div2.p: Arrived early. One mile to lot. Thunderstorm during afternoon; business fair.

div2.head: Thur. 13
Saratoga, N. Y.
Fitchburg and D. & H. C. 101.
div2.p: Arrived 7.30 A. M. One-mile haul to lot. Weather clear; business fair.

div2.head: Fri. 14
Schenectady, N. Y.
D. & H. C. 22.
div2.p: Arrived 4.30 A. M. Lot one mile from crossing. Weather clear; business good.

div2.head: Sat. 15
Utica, N. Y.
N. Y. C. & H. R. 78.
div2.p: Arrived 5.00 A. M. Unloaded close to lot. Weather clear; business very big. Sergt. Webb of the Rough Riders is sent to hospital here.

div2.head: Mon. 17
Syracuse, N. Y.
N. Y. C. & H. R. 41.
div2.p: Arrived early. Heavy rain all day Sunday, followed by a clear, warm day Monday; business big. Albert Zimes of the band injures his leg and is compelled to go to the hospital. Archie Clements also goes to the hospital, with a mild case of typhoid.

div2.head: Tues. 18
Binghamton, N. Y.
D., L. & W. 79.
div2.p: Arrived 7.00 A. M. Half-mile to lot. Weather clear; business big.

div2.head: Wed. 19
Elmira, N. Y.
D., L. & W. 57.
div2.p: Arrived 5:00 A. M. Two-mile haul to lot. Weather clear; business big. During the night performance a lady fell from the seats, breaking her leg.

div2.head: Thur. 20
Rochester, N. Y.
Erie. 112.
div2.p: Arrived 7.30 A. M. Two miles to lot; business immense at both performances.

div2.head: Fri. 21 and Sat. 22
Buffalo, N. Y.
N. Y. C. & H. R. 67.
div2.p: Arrived early. A heavy rain during afternoon puts the lot in very bad condition; however, the tent was filled at both performances Friday. Saturday, weather clear; business very big. Many members of the company visit the Falls.

div2.head: Mon. 24
Cleveland, O.
L. S. & M. S. 183.
div2.p: Arrived 10.30 Sunday. Weather clear; business very big; doors closed at night. Jack Dawson fell and fractured his ankle; he was taken to the hospital here.

div2.head: Tues. 25
Akron, O.
C. T. & V. 35.
div2.p: Arrived 6.30 A. M. Half-mile haul. A heavy thunderstorm came up during the afternoon, but cleared off at night; business very big.

div2.head: Wed. 26
Canton, O.
C. T. & V. 14.
div2.p: Arrived 5.00 A. M. Tableau wagon No. 100 was upset near the runs, delaying the work a little. Weather very hot; business big.

div2.head: Thur. 27
Youngstown, O.
P. R. R. 55.
div2.p: Arrived early. Two miles to lot. Weather warm and clear; business big. Johnnie Baker loses his pocket-book, containing $240 and a valuable diamond pin, a gift of the colonel.

div2.head: Fri. 28
Beaver Falls, Pa.
P. R. R. 35.
div2.p: Arrived early. Weather very hot; business big. A five-gallon can of gasolene exploded in car 56. Ed Sullivan, the porter, and Jas. Parker, a canvasman, were very badly burned, and the car was totally destroyed; the injured men were taken to the hospital here.

div2.head: Sat. 29
Stuebenville, O.
P.R.R. 50.
div2.p: First section arrived 5.00 A. M., the second did not get in till 9.00 A.M. A squall of wind struck the show about 6.30 P. M., but passed over without much damage.

div2.head: Mon. 31
Coshocton, O.
P.R.R. 81.
div2.p: Arrived 6.30 A. M. Weather clear; business good. A ball game was played between a Wild West Nine and the local club yesterday, resulting in a sweeping victory for the Wild West. Score: 14 to 0.

div2.head: Tues. 1
Mansfield, O.
P. R. R. 78.
div2.p: Arrived early. Very soft lot. Weather clear; very big afternoon house. Fred Essex of the band closes.

div2.head: Wed. 3
Upper Sandusky, O.
P. R. R. 78.
div2.p: Arrived 5.00 A. M. One-mile haul to lot. Weather clear; business fair. J. McAdams joins the band.

div2.head: Thur. 3
Lima, O.
P. R. R. 44.
div2.p: Arrived early. One mile to lot; big business. A heavy thunderstorm came up during evening. Miller of the Rough Riders is taken to the hospital with typhoid. Sergeant Webb returns from hospital at Utica.

div2.head: Fri. 4
Muncie, Ind.
L. E. & W. 85
div2.p: Arrived 6.30. A heavy rainstorm, accompanied with thunder and lightning, keeps the lot in bad shape; business fair. Fred Hoffman (Fritz) is sent to the hospital with a broken leg.

div2.head: Sat. 5
Fort Wayne, Ind.
L. E. & W. 65.
div2.p: Arrived early. Lot two miles from town; immense business; doors closed. Little Mary, Indian papoose, died suddenly here.

div2.head: Mon. 7
Hillsdale, Mich.
L. S. & M. S. 71.
div2.p: Arrived 9.00 A. M. Half-mile haul to lot. Weather clear; business very big in afternoon, fair at night. Three of the Arabs close.

div2.head: Tues. 8
Jackson, Mich.
L. S. & M. S. 26.
div2.p: Arrived early. One-mile haul. Weather clear; business very big. A new sleeping car arrived, to take the place of one destroyed at Beaver Falls.

div2.head: Wed. 9
Lansing, Mich.
M. C. 36.
div2.p: Arrived 6.00 A. M. A mile and a half haul. Weather clear; business big. Ed Lacey of the Forepaugh-Sells Show pays us a visit.

div2.head: Thur. 10
Bay City, Mich.
M. C. 79.
div2.p: Arrived 6.30 A. M. One-mile haul to lot. Weather clear; business big.

div2.head: Fri. 11
Port Huron, Mich.
F. & P. M. 102.
div2.p: Arrived 7.30 A. M. A wind storm struck the show about 1.30 P. M. and blew down the front end. However, things were soon straightened out, and the show went on a usual; business big.

div2.head: Sat. 12
Detroit, Mich.
G. T. R. 58.
div2.p: Arrived early. Three-quarter-mile haul. Weather clear. Lot very hard and rough. One of the Filipinos has a fall, and is badly shaken up. Flat Iron returns from hospital at Utica.
Lot—Grand River Ave. and Hudson St.

div2.head: Mon. 14
Toledo, O.
M. C. 60.
div2.p: Arrived early and unloaded close to lot. Weather clear; enormous business. James Warren leaves for Chicago. Three of the English soldiers close.

div2.head: Tues. 15
Defiance, O.
Wabash. 51.
div2.p: Arrived 5.00 A. M. Weather clear; business very big.

div2.head: Wed. 16
Peru, Ind.
Wabash. 100.
div2.p: Arrived 7.00 A. M. One-mile haul. Weather clear and warm; afternoon house full, evening fair. Mr. Bailey leaves for Chicago to arrange for lights, etc.

div2.head: Thur. 17
Lafayette, Ind.
Wabash. 52.
div2.p: Arrived early. One-mile haul to lot. Weather clear; business big in afternoon, fair at evening. Jere Murphy, a trainman, has his foot severely injured by a wagon passing over it.

div2.head: Fri. 18
Bloomington, Ill.
L. E. & W. 116.
div2.p: Arrived 8.30. One mile to lot. Weather very hot; business good in afternoon, fair at night.

div2.head: Sat. 19
Peoria, Ill.
L. E. & W. 40.
div2.p: Arrived early. Weather very hot. Gave two performances to packed houses and pulled out of town at 11.45.

div2.head: Mon. 21—Tues. 22—Wed. 23—Thur. 24— Fri. 25—Sat. 26—Sun. 27
Chicago, Ill.—C., R. I. & P. 161.
div2.p: We reached here at 6.00 A. M., after an exceptionally fast run from Peoria.

A grand stand had been erected, to take the place of our regular reserved seats. The Battle Scene was also greatly strengthened by fifty additional men, and the erection of a much larger hill than that used on the road.
The weather during the entire week was warm and clear, and the business tremendous—there being thousands turned away every evening.
On Friday, August 25th, it was found necessary to put in the extra forty-five foot middle piece, in order to put up more seats to accommodate the crowds.
There were fourteen performances given during our stay here, which terminated on Sunday evening, August 27th.
A large number of the show employés closed here during the week.

div2.head: Mon. 28
Milwaukee, Wis.
C. & N. W. 85.
div2.p: Arrived 7.00 A. M. Three and a half miles haul to lot, which proves to be very hard and rough. Weather clear; business very big at both performances. Wm. Baker, the boy giant, closes.

div2.head: Tues. 29
Fond du Lac, Wis.
C. & N. W. 63.
div2.p: Arrived 6.00 A. M. One-mile haul to lot. Weather clear; business very big in afternoon, fair at night.

div2.head: Wed. 30
Madison, Wis.
C. & N. W. 89.
div2.p: Arrived 4.30 A. M. Lot three quarters of a mile from railroad. Weather clear; business very big.

div2.head: Thur. 31
Winona, Minn.
C. & N.W. 159.
div2.p: Arrived 6.30 A. M., after fast run. One mile to lot. Weather cloudy with rain; business big. Roughest lot of the season.

div2.head: Fri. 1
Rochester, Minn.
C. & N. W. 50.
div2.p: Arrived early. Two-mile haul to lot. Weather cloudy; business big in afternoon, fair at night.

div2.head: Sat. 2
Mankato, Minn.
C. & N. W. 84.
div2.p: Arrived 5.30 A. M. Lot one half mile from crossing. Weather clear; business big in afternoon, light at night.

div2.head: Fri. 29
Centerville, Iowa.
C., M. & St. P. and Iowa Cent. 126.
A Few Statistics.
div2.p: Starting from Bridgeport, Ct., on April 14th, the "Wild West" traveled a distance of 11,111 miles, using the tracks of forty different railroads.

The show was on the road 200 days, during which time 341 performances were given, 132 towns visited in twenty-four States, viz: one stand of two and one-half weeks, four one-week stands, five two-day, and 122 one-day, on seven of which only one performance was given.

There were 529 people employed in all departments, the "Wild West" stable contained 325 horses, and the baggage stock numbered 119 head. The shortest run from one stand to the next was seven miles, from Lawrence, Mass., to Haverill, the longest, 205 miles, from Kirksville, Mo., to St. Louis.

For transportation purposes the show used thirty-five baggage wagons, two band wagons, two water tanks, two engines for electric light, four buggies, two field pieces and caissons and one Gatling gun. The trains consisted of sixteen flat cars, fifteen stock cars and eight sleeping coaches. The show carried eighty lengths of blue seats and eleven sections of reserved seats, giving seating accommodation to approximately 13,000 people.

div2.head: Past Seasons with the Wild West.

div3.p:
The Buffalo Bill Wild West Show was organized as an outdoor show in 1883, and opened in Omaha, Neb., in May, and traveled through the States of Nebraska, Iowa, Illinois, Kentucky, Indiana, Pennsylvania, New York, Connecticut, Massachusetts and Rhode Island, giving the performance in 50
Fair Grounds with the exception of Coney Island, where a temporary stand was erected, and they remained there five weeks. It was at this place that the first horse race was ever given by electric light.

Opened in May, in St. Louis, Mo., went through the Eastern States and Canada. October 31st took a boat down the Mississippi River, bound for New Orleans. The boat was wrecked at Rodney, Miss., and everything was lost except horses. Opened in New Orleans Christmas week, and closed April 1, 1885, then worked north through the Central and Southern States, including Michigan and Wisconsin, and closed October 31st at St. Louis, Mo.

Opened in St. Louis in May, and then played through to New York, where they opened a season at Erastina, Staten Island, in June, and remained until September 30th, then opened a winter season at Madison Square Garden, Thanksgiving Eve, and closed Washington's Birthday, 1887. During their stay at the Garden they lost sixteen buffaloes, from lung trouble.

April 1st, sailed on the steamer "State of Nebraska" for London, England, where they remained a season of six months, and then went to Manchester, England, for six months, and closed April 30, 1888; then gave one performance at Hull, England, in the afternoon, and sailed the same night for New York City on the steamer "Persian Monarch."

Opened the season at Erastina, Staten Island, on Decoration Day, and remained six
51
weeks; then went to Philadelphia, Baltimore and Washington, and closed at the State Fair in Richmond, Va., October 22d.

Sailed April 12th on the Steamer "Persian Monarch" for Havre, France, where a season of six months was played at Paris. They then toured through France, Spain, Italy, Germany and Austria, and closed in the City of Strasburg, Alsace-Lorraine, October 29, 1890. Some of the troupe returned to the United States, while others remained there.

Opened in Stuttgart, April 15th, and played through Germany, Belgium and England; closed at Croyden, England, October 31st. Opened again at Glasgow, Scotland, November 15th, and remained until April 15, 1892. May 9th opened again in London, and closed October 27, 1892, and sailed on the Steamer "Mohawk," October 29th, for New York City.

This was the World's Fair season. There was a Grand Stand erected at 62d and 63d streets and Grace Avenue, Chicago, with a seating capacity of 20,000 people. It was opened April 26th, and closed October 31st, making 186 days of continuous performance; not one show was missed, and it closed the most successful season known in show history.
Opened in Ambrose Park, Brooklyn, N. Y., May 12th, and closed October 6th. One show was missed September 14th, on account of heavy rain; no Sunday shows were given, making a run of 126 days.
